# Example Markdown Document ## Headers Markdown supports different levels of headers: ## Emphasis You can add emphasis using: - **Bold text**: `**Bold text**` or `__Bold text__` - *Italic text*: `*Italic text*` or `_Italic text_` - ***Bold and italic text***: `***Bold and italic text***` ### Unordered List - Item 1 - Item 2 - Subitem 2.1 - Subitem 2.2 - Item 3 ### Ordered List 1. First item 2. Second item 1. Subitem 2.1 2. Subitem 2.2 3. Third item ## Links and Images You can add links and images: - [Link to Perplexity](https://www.perplexity.ai/) - Image of Markdown Logo ## Blockquotes > This is a blockquote. Blockquotes are great for highlighting quotes or important information. ## Code ### Inline Code Use backticks for `inline code`. ### Code Block ```python def hello_world(): print("Hello, world!") hello_world() ``` ## Tables You can create tables to display data: | Name | Age | Occupation | |----------| | Alice | 30 | Engineer | | Charlie | 35 | Teacher | ## Footnotes Here's a sentence with a footnote.[^1] [^1]: This is the footnote text. # Heading 1 This is a paragraph with a citation [1] and some text. ## Heading 2 - Bullet list item 1 - Bullet list item 2 with emoji ðŸ˜Š 1. Numbered list item 1 2. Numbered list item 2 > Blockquote with some text. >> Nested blockquote. Indented code block | Table Header 1 | Table Header 2 | | -------------- | -------------- | | Cell 1 | Cell 2 | | Cell 3 | Cell 4 | --- Standalone line with punctuation! "This is a quoted text."

This is an HTML paragraph.

$$ x = y + z $$ Fallback content that doesn't fit other categories.
